header.title: Sexism in Harry Potter
header.subtitle: NA
header.postText: Watch in HD and full screen for best results. Type in sexism in ... fill in the blank with whatever want. All you ever hear or read about is how something is sexist to women. It's very unusual to hear people address how something is sexist to men.  My problem is not so much with the sexist moments in this book series (although, I must say they aren't exactly my favorite parts) but my main issue is with the fact that nobody ever brings these obvious sexist moments up when they talk about 'Sexism in Harry Potter' Most people sooner recognize non-existent sexism against women than they do clear-cut sexism against men.

I never did understand the stairs thing. I mean, yes... if you are going to "protect" one sex from potentially harmful encounters then why not do it for both? Forgive me if I touch on uncomfortable subjects, but let's be honest. The stairs were put into place to prevent unwanted coupling at the school. The founders in their time (a thousand years ago according to the books) obviously knew that passions could flair at the school (which is filled with young people, because it's what boys and girls do) and you could have students coupling. Knowing that they could not possibly stop this, the the founders obviously felt that they should limit the responsibility of the school by preventing it INSIDE the school... at least in a most obvious place it could happen. In the bed chamber areas. (Because yes, most people would like to do it on something soft like a bed) Now yes, we know there are some aggressive boys out there who might want to press their advantage... and who is to say that the founders didn't catch people doing the nasty in the girl's dorms? But let us remember that we are talking about a world in which magic exists. As proven by the story of Voldemort, it is possible to misuse magic to supplant the will of a person. That's what Voldemort's mom did to his dad. So anyway, they place a magical barrier (which mind you would be rendered useless to a male student that knows how to fly like, oh... I don't know Voldemort) to prevent any coupling in the girl's dorm, yet they didn't think that the opposite could be true? That you could have some sexually aggressive girls? Or that perhaps you could have a female sexual predator? Does J.K. Rowling subscribe to the idea that you can't rape a man? Or a boy? That a girl or a woman couldn't do something like that, even though it happens in real life? Or that simply a nice girl could want to go have a good time with a boy in HIS room? (Barring that the guy doesn't have any cockblocking friends, you can start to see that this is pretty ridiculous and has most likely happened a lot over the centuries) Again, I never got it. Now, I love women and girls. I come from t he old school and do believe that they should be respected and protected. And I will admit that I believe that they should be protected more than boys. But that's just how I was brought up. It's obviously a remnant of a by gone time in our history. An age where chivalry and good manners was the norm and expected from people. But now, the powers that be want everything to be equal. They want us to forget the old ways or modify them. Even my own beloved Emma Watson says that she can accept a man opening the door for her but would expect me to allow her to open the door for me. (And while I know in my heart that that's something called being polite, in my head I struggle to make myself accept that) But in an institution, like a school that needs to have rules for the it's student it is a given that those rules must be unbiased. So if you are going to protec t one sex then you should protect both or not have it at all. Maybe in the 19 years after the school was basically destroyed, the rebuilt school did away with this head scratching rule. Or perhaps, they instituted it for both dorms. But who knows? Perhaps the ruling elite of the Wizarding World (in England) still hold on to chivalry?

Well, just would like to point out that in Fantastic Beasts, MACUSA (the American Wizarding Government) had a female President in the 1920s. Looks like the Wizarding World is way more equal than Muggle World.

commentThread.commentText: I'm glad that you pointed out the sexism against male characters, but I still think the book contains some things that are directed at women. For example, Rowling claims that fifty percent of the Ministers for Magic have been female, but in the book we see four consecutive male Ministers and a male pronoun referring to a Prime Minister who would have in fact been Margaret Thatcher. There was no reason not to use the female pronoun other than Rowling's assumption that the previous PM would have been a man, and Thatcher definitely wasn't.

commentThread.commentText: Once again, inequality that is harmful to men can and does exist. No one is trying to dispute that. I'm only saying that men's gender-based issues shouldn't necessarily be labelled 'sexism' becaus e sexism isn't just discrimination based on an individual 's gender, it is systematic and pervasive othering where people who belong in the social minority are seen and treated as lesser than the ones in the dominant group. I think the use of the t erm sexism is appropriate in certain domains and for certain injustices such as being pressured to join the military etc. The examples that you mentioned though? The staircases were designed to protect women and the boys couldn't participate in the unicorn class not because of the teacher's misandrist views but because of the subject matter itself. Unfair, sure, but not really sexist. And you can discuss these things but why must you also put down a review of the harmful representation s of gender in the book? As I was saying in my previous comment (before YouTube cut me off,) speaking out for men and boys is a good thing so, by all means, continue. Just don't do it as criticism against feminism or to silence women's voices.

Mudblood. You know, it's common knowledge in feminism and other human rights movements that there is no such thing as 'reverse sexism' or 'reverse racism'. I'm not saying that men do not face injustices that women don't. That's no t sexism, however. That is not about women discriminating against men. Speaking out for men and boys is a good thing so, by all means, continue. Just don't do it as criticism against feminism or to silence women's voices.

commentThread.commentText: I might get a lot of hate for saying this, BUT: Even though Gundam SEED was was, it was (on retrospect) a better story than Harry Potter. Harry Potter having defeated Voldemort, gets to internalize Voldemort's REAL plan in conquering the world and defeating death (maybe even attaining "godhood", for the purpose of salvaging Humanity or some transcendental thing). In deciphering Voldemort's true intentions, Harry himself becomes a successor to Voldemort (so that Snape, and many more DON'T die) and quickly picks up most of the Death Eaters. Ironically, Lestrange refuses (along some other few Death Eaters) to join Harry, they are however (through Harry's influence) killed immediately by aurors. Soon HP climbs to power (Ginny and Snape as right his right hand), and during this time the Wizard World becomes known to muggles. It should be noted that this causes a mayority of muggles to be "ok with it", BUT a certain minority to become radicals in the extermination of wizards, like the Death Eaters were to extermination of muggles. The plot escalates to having 4 distinct bands: HP's Neo-Death Eaters (wizard extremists), wizard moderates, muggles moderates, and some muggle terrorist group. War soon becomes unavoidable. Harry Potter gets a lot of people into his side, wizard moderates only have a weak auror army (Ron, Hermione, Malfoy, and most of the DA), muggle moderates have (after formation of world government) a decimated army (HP recruited "gifted" muggles), and the muggle extremists will consist of a battalion of hardcore "gifted" and armed individuals. The curtain comes to a close, as the decimation of moderates (wizards and muggles) takes place. Humanity's population diminishes in this war. @Eyal Lev As I am not a child, a  homosexual or a woman, I do not know, nor do I care to know about "Harry Potter"

Mudblood is a derogatory term for a magic-sensitive character in the Harry Potter world, is born to non-magical muggle parents.  Notable examples are Hermione Granger and Lily Potter (nee Evans).  Muggle-born is a preferable term.

The reverse case of a muggle-born wizard, is known as a squib, who is a muggle born to at least one magical parent.  Notable examples are Hogwarts caretaker Argus Filtch, and neighbor to the Dursleys (Arabella Figg).
